thread.title: Aust market set to break winning run
thread.title_full: Aust market set to break winning run

title: Aust market set to break winning run
text:
Wed, Jul 22, 2015, 11:59 AM AEST - Australia Markets close in 4 hrs 1 mins Aust market set to break winning run AAP â€“ 29 minutes ago Print 
The Australian sharemarket looks set to break its six-session winning streak with weakness across all sectors. 
BHP Billiton shares have tumbled after the mining giant said it expects a hit of up to $US650 million ($A876.31 million) to its profits thanks to writedowns and redundancy costs in its copper business. 
At 1034 AEST its shares were down 23 cents at $26.59. 
CommSec market analyst Steve Daghlian said the weak start followed six days of solid gains on the Australian market 
"We've had a solid run but this morning all sectors are in the red with weaknesses across the board," he said. 
"BHP's results have been looked at with the most interest. There's solid production numbers but nothing is shooting the lights out and further writedowns are expected. However, other miners such as Fortescue and Newcrest are rising." 
Mr Daghlian said investors were keeping a close eye on two data releases on Wednesday - June's consumer price index report and a speech by Reserve Bank of Australia governor Glenn Stevens. 
"We're unlikely to see any major changes from the RBA's commentary and interest rate cuts are anticipated but whenever the RBA governor talks the market listens closely," he said. 
Among the big miners, at 1034 AEST, Rio Tinto was 33 cents worse off at $53.05, while Fortescue Metals was up 1.75 cents at $1.75. 
All the big four banks were lower with Westpac falling 33 cents at $34.57, National Australia Bank down 30 cents at $34.47, ANZ shedding 29 cents to $32.76 and the Commonwealth $1.04 worse off at $87.06. 
KEY FACTS 
* AT 1034 AEST, the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index was down 52.2 points, or 0.91 per cent, at 5,654.0 points. 
* The broader All Ordinaries index was down 48.7 points, or 0.86 per cent, at 5639.8 points. 
* At 1100 AEST the September share price index futures contract was down 51 points at 5,597 points, with 8,338 contracts traded. 
* At 1126 AEST, national turnover was 572,534,931 million securities worth $1.27 billion. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook
